docs.lead_paragraph: S.E.C. Seeks Information From a Unit of Berkshire Berkshire Hathaway, the company controlled by the billionaire Warren E. Buffett, said that federal regulators had requested information from its General Re insurance unit about the sale of products that can be used to smooth earnings. The company is the seventh insurer to have its practices examined by the Securities and Exchange Commission. But it is the first time Berkshire's insurance unit, long seen to reflect the professional integrity advocated by Mr. Buffett, has been drawn into the inquiry. [Page C3.] Social Security Debate Set to Start President Bush and Congress are preparing for a debate over the future of Social Security, whose solvency depends not only on factors including productivity, inflation and birth rates but also on how long beneficiaries will be living. And many population experts believe that life expectancy will increase rapidly in the 21st century, making the financial problems of Social Security even worse. [A1.] Best Buy Dropping Ernst & Young Best Buy will stop using Ernst & Young as its auditor in February because of an agreement it had with a former board member who served on the retailer's audit committee.[C3.] I.B.M. PC Unit Was Not Profitable I.B.M., which is selling its personal computer business to the Lenovo Group of China, said that division has not made a profit for three and a half years. [C4.] Judge Halts Import Curbs A federal judge temporarily barred the United States from imposing some curbs on imports of textiles and clothing from China. United States quotas on the textile trade, imposed 40 years ago, are set to expire on Saturday, ending a system that limited trade in 2,400 items, including cotton shirts and denim. [C4.] Russia to Control Yukos Unit Russia's minister of industry and energy, Viktor B. Khristenko, left, said the controlling stake in a subsidiary of the oil company Yukos, Yuganskneftegaz, would be transferred to a newly created state company and would not become part of the merger between Gazprom and Rosneft. That merger would be completed next month, he said, but the subsidiary would not ''be among the consolidated assets.'' [World Business, Section W.] Report on Prozac Documents The British Medical Journal said it had sent documents to American health regulators that it said appear to suggest a link between Prozac and suicidal behavior. [C5.] Stocks Mixed in Quiet Trading Stocks were mixed in a listless session. The Dow Jones industrials fell 28.89 points, to 10,800.30. The Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.1 of a point, to 1,213.55, and the Nasdaq composite gained 1.34 points, to 2,178.34. [C5.] Manufacturing Growth Slows The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago said that its business barometer declined to 61.2 this month, from 65.2 in November, a sign of slower growth in manufacturing. In a separate report, the Labor Department said that the number of Americans filing initial unemployment claims fell unexpectedly last week. [C2.] Oracle Fires 4 PeopleSoft Officials Oracle fired PeopleSoft's co-president, Kevin T. Parker, and three other top executives, a day after assuming control of the software maker in a $10.3 billion takeover. [C5.] Hormel Buys Clougherty Packing Hormel Foods acquired Clougherty Packing for $186 million, adding Dodger Dog hot dogs sold in Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles to its product line. [C3.] U.S. Bond Market to Close Early The United States bond market will close at 2 p.m. today in advance of New Year's holiday. The stock markets will have regular trading hours today.
docs.snippet: S.E.C. Seeks Information From a Unit of Berkshire  Berkshire Hathaway, the company controlled by the billionaire Warren E. Buffett, said that federal regulators had requested information from its General Re insurance unit about the sale of products...

docs.lead_paragraph: Montana's public universities must provide their gay employees with insurance coverage for their domestic partners, the state's Supreme Court ruled yesterday. The majority in the 4-to-3 decision said the decision had nothing to do with the rights of gay couples to marry. But a dissenting judge criticized his colleagues as ''radically altering common law marriage in Montana.''

headline.main: Montana Universities Must Offer Health Insurance to Gay Employees' Partners, Court Rules

docs.abstract: Montana Supreme Court rules that state's public universities must provide gay employees with insurance coverage for domestic partners because limiting coverage only to heterosexual couples violates equal protection clause of state Constitution (M)
docs.snippet: The majority in the Montana Supreme Court's 4-to-3 decision said the ruling had nothing to do with the rights of gay couples to marry.

docs.lead_paragraph: This is the moment when we list our priorities for the new year, counting off the most important social challenges the country faces and the remedies we'd like to see our elected officials adopt. Normally, we urge that all this be accomplished in a spirit of bipartisanship. All that requires a leap of faith that's beyond us this season. Instead, we'd like to pick out a few areas that may be a little lower on the agenda, but where the need is aching and the potential bridges between the parties are already clear and sturdy. All it takes is a few people to start walking across. WORLD HUNGER -- The collapse of international communism has produced one important political byproduct in the United States: foreign aid programs have become less politically charged. Something that was once seen as the province of the left has been enthusiastically embraced by many conservatives, as has the forgiveness of foreign debt. The Republican base within the evangelical community has also had a longstanding interest in helping the poorest of the poor abroad.
docs.abstract: Editorial on some important domestic and international issues on which progress could be made in new year: world hunger, sex trafficking, health care, agricultural subsidies and campaign finance reform
docs.snippet: This is the moment when we list our priorities for the new year, counting off the social challenges the country faces and the remedies we'd like to see adopted.

docs.lead_paragraph: At least once a year for a decade, Nancy Bowes has left her home in Michigan and journeyed to the Plaza Hotel's celebrated Oak Room restaurant for dinner and a taste of history. She likes to visit over the holidays, when small Christmas trees flank the room's French doors, strings of lights brighten the place, and delicate white-painted branches cover the large carved pillars that rise solidly from the rear of the room. On Tuesday evening, Mrs. Bowes accompanied her sister and niece, Oak Room first-timers both, for a pre-theater dinner. ''It's a legend,'' she said.

headline.main: Oak Room at the Plaza Hotel Is Going the Way of the Pince-Nez

docs.snippet: The Plaza Hotel's celebrated Oak Room restaurant is closing, along with One C.P.S. and the Oyster Bar.

docs.lead_paragraph: Across the country, doctors are struggling to decide which pain relievers to prescribe now that they know that popular drugs like Vioxx and Celebrex pose potentially serious heart risks. ''We are desperately in need of information,'' said Dr. Stephen Brenner, an internist in New Haven. Yet for at least two years, doctors at the Mayo Clinic, the federal Veterans Affairs Department and the Kaiser Permanente health plan have been sharply limiting their use of Vioxx and Celebrex. That is because those three institutions, after undertaking separate reviews of test data available on various painkillers, reached the same conclusion: For most patients, Vioxx, Celebrex and a related drug, Bextra, did not work any better than older pain relievers or provide any safety benefits beyond them.

headline.main: Doctors, Too, Ask: Is This Drug Right?

docs.abstract: Article on series Medicine's Data Gap: Clinical Trials, Practical Uses focuses on doctors' need of information on pain relievers to prescribe now that they know that popular drugs like Vioxx and Celebrex pose potentially serious heart risks; holds for at least two years, doctors at Mayo Clinic, federal Veterans Affairs Department and Kaiser Permanente health plan have been sharply limiting their use of Vioxx and Celebrex; three institutions, after undertaking separate reviews of test data available on various painkillers, reached same conclusion: for most patients, Vioxx, Celebrex and related drug, Bextra, did not work any better than older pain relievers or provide any safety benefits beyond them; growing number of health care organizations are scrutinizing findings about all drugs, new and old, available to treat particular health condition to determine which work best at lowest cost; Dr Eric L Matteson, rheumatologist with Mayo Clinic, says evidence-based reviews can balance drug pitches; Dr Stephen Brenner, internist at Yale New Haven Hospital, comments; graph; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Doctors are struggling to decide which pain relievers to prescribe now that they know that drugs like Vioxx and Celebrex pose serious heart risks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly half of New York City households do not earn enough to pay for their basic living costs, according to a report produced by a New York nonprofit that works to make poor women financially independent. In fact, the report estimates that the income needed to afford basic living costs in the city is more than three times the national poverty level. Researchers used government standards on housing, food, child care and medical insurance to calculate the basic costs.

headline.main: Basic Costs Beyond Reach Of Many in City, Report Says

docs.snippet: Nearly half of New York City households do not earn enough to pay for their basic living costs, according to a report produced by a New York women's center.

docs.lead_paragraph: The doctor pulled out a stethoscope and Gladys Martinez stopped smiling. She inhaled. Her heart-shaped earrings trembled. The doctor listened. Two years ago, Mrs. Martinez survived a heart attack. Stethoscopes remain a cold reminder, the dreaded moment of any medical exam.

headline.main: The Doctor Will See You ... at Home; Hospitals Add House Calls for Older Patients

docs.snippet: As New York's population ages, several hospitals use house calls to improve care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even after a decade under a Republican administration that made tax cutting a priority, New York State still burdens its businesses with such high taxes and other costs that its ability to create and keep jobs is being hurt, a business lobbying group said on Tuesday. In updating its report on the price of doing business in the state, the group, the Public Policy Institute of the Business Council of New York State, said it had found that many costs -- including the average premium for health insurance, the average cost of a workers' compensation case, the retail price of electricity and natural gas and unemployment insurance taxes -- are higher in New York than in most other states.

headline.main: Doing Business Is Too Costly in New York, Policy Group Says

docs.snippet: New York State still burdens its businesses with such high taxes that its ability to create and keep jobs is being hurt, a business lobbying group said on Tuesday.
